name: Gene Mumford
comments: Doo-wop/R&B tenor singer from North Carolina.  Mumford was arrested in 1945 on charges of housebreaking, unlawful entry, and assault with intent to rape and convicted in 1947, receiving a lengthy prison sentence; he worked on a chain gang.  At the urging of Mumford's father, additional investigation was undertaken producing a new solid alibi witness, and Mumford was pardoned in 1949, when his musical career began in earnest.  He was also a songwriter.

Yet, during his enlistment, he performed as a soloist with The Army Band, held the position of lead trumpet in the "Army Blues" and was principal trumpet in the White House Herald Trumpets. Stahl has backed up notables like Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Tony Bennett, Mel Torme, Jack Jones, Sarah Vaughan, and Englebert Humperdinck. In April 1977 Stahl formed his own band, The Dave Stahl Band.

He moved to Toronto in 1957 where he had a successful career composing commercials and scores for films and television. In October 2002 the College of Music at the University of Western Ontario was renamed the Don Wright Faculty of Music in his honor.

name: Carrie Jacobs-Bond
comments: From Janesville, Wisconsin, Jacobs-Bond - a songwriter, singer and pianist - overcame many hardships to become the first woman in America to establish a music publishing firm (in Chicago), which she did in order to have an outlet for her own work when she could not get the male-dominated publishing houses to issue it.  Her father died when Jacobs-Bond was young; she had a short unhappy marriage that resulted in divorce in 1887, then married her childhood sweetheart, Dr. Frank Bond, who died in 1895 from the consequences of a fall caused by a child's snowball.  Her only child, a son, committed suicide in 1932. Bond-Jacobs was the first American female composer to sell over one million copies of sheet music for a song, "I Love You Truly".  Her most successful work was "A Perfect Day" published in 1910, which sold 25 million copies of sheet music.  Jacobs-Bond was part of the 1970 inaugural class inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

name: Patricia Routledge

She won the 1968 Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical for her role in "Darling of the Day" and the 1988 Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical for "Candide".

name: New Princes' Toronto Band
comments: Dance orchestra in the 1920s. This band were: Hal Swain (saxophonist from Toronto, Canada); Billy Hall (trombone/sax); Frank Walsh (piano/organ); Dave Caplan (banjo); Ran Garrison (sousaphone, trombone & sax) and Ken Kenny (drums). Swain departed in 1926 and Caplan became the leader of the band (now with Harry Hoffman and Art Christmas) taking on his name as "Dave Caplan's Toronto Band". By the time this band toured Berlin in the summer of 1926 the line-up had changed further; Dave Caplan, Les Allen, Lorne Cole, Harry Hoffman, Laurie Day, Art Christmas, Arthur Lousley, Arthur Calkin and Jack Collins.
